comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Well, unless they spelt themselves differently, they weren't there in 1901. The only rural Conaghers are in Ballyshiel, Co. Down. It's not close enough to the border that you'd mistake it for Antrim.

comment._content: There's no end of McKinleys, mind you.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Dervrock it is, according to the Belfast News-letter The Belfast News-Letter , Saturday, July 2, 1898
WEEKLY ILLUSTRATED NEWSPAPERS "THE SKETCH" this week has some interesting pictures of the home of President McKinley's forefathers at Dervrock, County Antrim. These include Conagher's farm, on which they lived, their burying place, and the spot in Coleraine where a grand-uncle of the President was hanged for treason in 1798.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I'll guess here. This farm has an entrance directly from "Conogher Cross Roads".

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: McKinley served as president from March 7 1897, so I'd venture to suggest that it's unlikely to be before that

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: This photo is very interesting for me personally, because it shows what this room might have looked like 100+ years ago. The room is in a cottage on the coast of southwest Scotland (from which you can see the Mourne Mountains on a (very) clear day), so not a million miles from Antrim.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: What a fabulous picture of country life on a prosperous farm. The long gun on the rafters, the large hearth capable of having two points of heat and a twin crane for hanging the pots and kettles. Two irons by the blazing fire and a shirt laid out on the child's bed beside which is a comfortable settle bed on which sits a fine fluffy toy elephant.  There is a large recess and a small cupboard which would hold sugar, salt, spices and such delights in a dry state. The bedrooms are in the most sensible place to the back of the fireplace and there is a timber 'rack' and timber chairs and stools so that everyone would feel welcome in this pleasant home. Visitors would sit by the fire beneath a strong ring where meat could be hung and a horseshoe from which luck would fall on all who visited.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: Hi Carol, do you mean the door beside the paraffin lamp with scalloped mirror? A latch has been removed from it but there seems to be a knob remaining and there is a lot of light coming in above the door. Not permanently sealed, perhaps. I see the red fire painting the room and flickering on the legs of women while the scalloped mirror on the paraffin lamp sent its light in gentle rays along their faces.  There is a similar one for sale in Purcell's Auctioneers at the moment for anyone who should like to reproduce the effect.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
